title: Minnesota Bids to Segregate its Child-Welfare Agencies
summary: No matter what problems they solve, laws granting different rights to different races are unconstitutional.. Should the law require state child-welfare authorities to treat black children differently from white children? Lawmakers in Minnesota may soon vote on a bill to do just that. The Minnesota African American Family Preservation Act's sponsors say it will address racial disparities in the state's foster-care system. African-American and mixed-race children are substantially more likely than white children to be reported to child-protective services.

title: What Kind of Voter Supports Mike Bloomberg?

summary: Sekiko Sakai Garrison says presidential candidate told her to 'kill it' when he learned she was pregnant. A woman who says Michael Bloomberg told her to terminate her pregnancy while she worked for his financial-data company the 1990s has been released from a nondisclosure agreement that prevented her from discussing the allegations, her lawyer said Friday.

title: Why Won't the CFTC Let You Take a Position on the Election?
summary: The commission prohibits political bets except those under $850 and for 'research purposes.'. Bernie Sanders is going to win, you could short luxury-goods manufacturers. Or if you're betting on Sen. Elizabeth Warren's chances, you could plan to buy shares of Ancestry.com in the event that the DNA testing company's long-rumored IPO finally takes place.

title: Stocks Suffer Biggest Weekly Losses Since 2008

title: Coronavirus Tests Europe's Differing Health Systems
summary: Europe is a patchwork of nation states through which people travel freely, making it easy for the coronavirus to spread. As the coronavirus spills across borders in Europe, the continent-with its patchwork of nation states through which people travel freely-faces a test of how well it can cooperate. Adding to the challenge, the spread of the virus comes during the winter, when the region's health systems are under most strain.

title: 'Unbelievers' Review: Fearful, Faithless
summary: It wasn't the books of Hobbes and Spinoza that shook the faith of the people. Rather, the people's weakening religious certainty cleared the ground for godless philosophers.. Of theso-called New Atheist writers who have churned out popular books in recent years, none has enjoyed more oracular authority among devotees than the sociobiologist Richard Dawkins. Mr. Dawkins deploys his expertise in evolutionary theory to cudgel the feeblest sparring partners that he can find: usually unnamed biblical literalists and fundamentalists. The technique is inevitably more condescending than edifying. Indeed, Mr. Dawkins's signature polemical move is to infantilize his opponents. Reasoned natural science, he dubiously insists, can all but disprove theism. Only a stubbornness born of mental immaturity, superstition or fear can explain the atavism of religious belief. The task, as the supercilious title of his recent "beginners guide" to atheism has it, is to "outgrow God."

title: U.K. Regulator Asks Accounting Firms to Wall-Off Audit Practice, Install Separate Board
summary: The new rules are aimed at improving audit quality in Britain. A U.K. regulator for audit and accounting is asking professional services firms to ringfence their audit practices and put in place independent boards amid increased concerns around audit quality in Britain.

title: 'Anointed With Oil' Review: The Crude Versus the Refined
summary: From the day it was ﬁrst reﬁned, oil has been seen as one of God's blessings on America and its holy mission in the world.. The modern American oil industry traces its origin to the summer of 1859 when Edwin Drake's 70-foot well found an immense deposit of oil in Titusville, Pa. At a time when a rising population created a demand for light that the whale-oil industry could no longer supply, and when the industrial revolution was creating an unprecedented demand for both fuel and machine lubricants, the discovery of large quantities of "rock oil" in accessible deposits close to the burgeoning cities of the East Coast unleashed a wave of wildcat exploration and technological development that would transform the American and world economies, underwrite the expansion of American world power in the 20th century, and, some would argue, ultimately threaten the future of human civilization as carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gasses emitted by the refining and burning of oil and its frequent companion natural gas fueled a dramatic rise in global temperatures.

title: Accountant Pleads Guilty Ahead of Trial in Panama Papers Case
summary: Richard Gaffey is the second individual to plead guilty in a tax-evasion case linked to documents leaked from a Panama law firm. An accountant pleaded guilty in federal court to charges he helped a client evade U.S. taxes in a case stemming from a trove of leaked documents known as the Panama Papers.

I trawl design fairs, consume niche interiors magazines, write books about other people's interiors. There is not a micro-trend, leg nuance or upholstery style that escapes the reach of my sofa board on Pinterest.

summary: These photos of stunning patterned floors, 'hardcore' décor and trendy interiors shrunk to dollhouse-size will keep you scrolling. summary: Take the debates away from the networks-they have too little substance, too much focus on au courant frivolousness such as tweet insults and too much time spent on attempting "gotchas.". You can have capitalism without government but you can't have socialism without a government.

title: It's Past Time to Actively Stop Evil Hackers
summary: Insecure communication systems let hackers infiltrate executive accounts remotely via phishing attacks or attacks on passwords or even on servers.. Insecure communication systems let hackers infiltrate executive accounts remotely via phishing attacks or attacks on passwords or even on servers ("Hackers Aid Rise in Wire-Transfer Scams," Business & Finance, Feb. 24). From there, they can learn and mimic the writing style of the target, and then masquerade as that individual to send digital instructions for wire transfers, file transfers, the sharing of privileged information or whatever else they please. Your company's fate is in the hacker's hands.

title: Trump's Record On Leading Epidemic Response Is Poor
summary: President Trump's proposed budget, released Feb. 10, includes a 16% cut to the CDC. The president has also called for a $65 million decrease in funding to the World Health Organization.. Regarding Daniel Henninger's "Trump Versus the Coronavirus" (Wonder Land, Feb. 27): Even after the spread of the virus had become clear, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention was hit with a hiring freeze by way of an executive order on Jan. 22. Vacancies in 125 job categories were blocked from being filled, including several in the Center for Preparedness and Response and others in offices handling infectious diseases. The National Institutes of Health isn't allowed reassignments, so vacancies in necessary epidemiology and virology personnel cannot be filled that way.

title: Removing the Obstacles and Changing People's Minds
summary: Amen to getting your way by removing obstacles. I wanted to work for a local entrepreneur, and we had two good meetings, but no offer emerged.. Amen to getting your way by removing obstacles ("How to Change Anyone's Mind," Review, Feb. 22). I wanted to work for a local entrepreneur, and we had two good meetings, but no offer emerged. In the third meeting I said: "Let's make this easier . . . Don't hire me. No salary, insurance, office, etc." I named a monthly fee and said I would work on a trial basis from home, 20 hours a week, for 90 days, on whatever projects were important to him. At the end of 90 days we'd both know if it was working, and we could either part ways as friends or change the deal. He agreed. I started the next day, and 60 days later he asked how soon I could go full time. We stayed together until he sold the company. Removing obstacles was the key.

title: The Joy of Watching TV With Headphones On
summary: These noise-canceling cans let you tune out racket and tune into an evening of solo TV. I MADE THE DECISION around hour five. summary: From the author, most recently, of 'The Splendid and the Vile: A Saga of Churchill, Family and Defiance During the Blitz.'. By Joseph Goebbels (Translated and edited by Fred Taylor, 1983)

title: 'Franklin & Washington' Review: Friends at the Founding
summary: If the restrained Washington was his country's father, the gregarious Franklin was its approachable uncle.. At a time when American politics is increasingly dominated by rancor, turbulence and division, it is perhaps unsurprising that books about the Republic's revered Founding Fathers are as popular as ever. To authors and publishers, the select band of men who championed independence from Britain and hammered out the Constitution resemble a pack of cards to be endlessly reshuffled and dealt out in different hands. Alongside biographies or group portraits of the Founders, another approach is to examine a pair whose alliance-or, more often, rivalry-is credited with forging the nation. Recently, for example, Alexander Hamilton was separately linked with George Washington, Thomas Jefferson and his nemesis, Aaron Burr, while several eminent historians have been drawn to the power struggle between Jefferson and John Adams.

title: 'The Boston Massacre' Review: Colonial Boston's Civil War
summary: Bostonians refused to be forced to house British soldiers. So the army paid rent to willing landlords, and soldiers' families settled down all over town.. Soldiers are people too. That's an obvious truth for soldiers and soldiers' families, but too often they are spoken of as tools to be sent, for good or for evil, depending on who is doing the sending. When we remember past wars, soldiers get lost in the search for straight-forward lessons. Highly charged debates over the Civil War leave little room for the individual motives of those who fought on either side, whereas for the American Revolution, British soldiers have long been the undifferentiated bad guys, tools of an empire violently trying to constrain an independent people. The "Boston Massacre" of 1770 seems proof of that portrayal, even if not quite in the melodramatic terms of Patriot Joseph Warren, who at the second annual commemoration in 1772 recalled "our children subjected to the barbarous caprice of the raging soldiery; our beauteous virgins exposed to all the insolence of unbridled passion."

title: Fiction: Secrets, Silences and Stage Disguises
summary: The novelist daughter of a superstar actress explores the illusions and realities of her mother's celebrity.. Norah, the daughter of the film and stage superstar Katherine O'Dell and the narrator of Anne Enright's latest novel, "Actress" (Norton, 264 pages, $26.95), touches the central trouble with her upbringing in a parenthetical aside offered so casually that it's easy to miss. While recounting her mother's brief Hollywood marriage, which began and ended before Norah was born, she tries to picture the glamorous wedding. "How does an actor say, 'I do,' up there in front of the congregation?" she wonders. "This was something I worried about as a child-how does an actor mean things?"

title: 'Writers & Lovers' Review: Kidding on the Square
summary: In Lily King's latest, a young writer adrift in Cambridge, Mass., ﬁghts off doubts about the life she's chosen.. One evening when I was in my late 20s and still in graduate school, the phone rang in my studio apartment. To call it a "studio" is overselling the place: It was a closet with a bay window carved out of a West Philadelphia row house. There was room for a foldout couch, a reading lamp and a table on which sat a stack of scholarly books and a much shorter stack of paper representing two chapters of my dissertation, which I had been writing for the past five years. I was single and scraping by on part-time adjunct teaching jobs.

title: Martha Clare Morris Devised a Diet to Reduce Risks of Dementia
summary: Rush University researcher praised blueberries and published book including her daughter's recipes. Martha Clare Morris, director of Rush University's Institute for Healthy Aging, conducted studies suggesting that a healthier diet reduces the risks of Alzheimer's disease and other forms of dementia.

title: SEC Charges South Carolina Companies, Executives in Failed Nuclear Project Case
summary: Scana Corp., two of its former senior executives and a subsidiary were charged with defrauding investors. Two South Carolina companies and two former top executives face civil fraud charges in relation to a failed nuclear power plant expansion project, the Securities and Exchange Commission said Thursday.

title: Photos of the Week
summary: Harvey Weinstein convicted of sex crimes, U.S. stocks slide into a correction over virus fears, Fury defeats Wilder for WBC heavyweight championship and more. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Children's Books: Sailing Over the Wall
summary: In a picture book based on real events, two Berlin families take a gamble in the fall of 1979.. At a time when the idea of socialism seems to be gaining appeal among young Americans, along comes "Flight for Freedom" (Chronicle, 56 pages, $17.99) to remind us how desperate people were to escape the reality of it during the Cold War.

title: Mysteries: Secrets From the Cutting Room
summary: Elizabeth Little's satirical novel brings together a socially inept film editor, a domineering director-and an unsolved murder on an island off the Delaware coast.. Film editor Marissa Dahl, the narrator of Elizabeth Little's "Pretty as a Picture" (Viking, 338 pages, $27), is a whiz at her craft, but her social skills are deplorable. "When faced with any real conversational pressure," she admits, "my personality just goes offline." Her social abilities are strained to the breaking point when, after signing a 16-page nondisclosure agreement, she is whisked out of her Southern California comfort zone and onto an island off the Delaware coast-there to serve Tony Rees, "the most exacting director in Hollywood."

title: 'There Was a Time' Review: The Glamour of Grit
summary: James Brown toured nonstop and ran his own record- and concert-promotion business as well.. For a performer who never shied away from self-gilding hyperbole, James Brown actually had it right when he called himself "the Hardest Working Man in Show Business." In a remarkably fertile period bracketed by his early-'60s crossover hits and his last great record (1973's "The Payback"), Brown ruled the R&B charts and invented funk music while also running James Brown Enterprises, his record and concert-promotion business. For Brown the businessman, that meant steering clear of the racist covenants that blocked performers of color from playing mainstream venues and instead leaning hard into the "Chitlin' Circuit," the loose agglomeration of barns, college gyms and traditional venues (including the Apollo in New York) that welcomed African-American performers and their fans.

title: 'Theodor Herzl' Review: Prophet of Self-Determination
summary: Admirers thought him a latter-day Moses. For others, his dream of a homeland was delusional, even blasphemous.. On Theodor Herzl's untimely death in Austria in 1904, a 17-year-old in a Polish village wrote: "The sun is gone, but its light will shine again, the seeds of renaissance which he sowed in our hearts will not remain frozen forever!" The teenager's name was David Ben-Gurion; 44 years later, he would stand beneath Herzl's portrait and read out Israel's declaration of independence. Soon after, as prime minister, he would reinter Herzl's remains atop one of Jerusalem's hills.

title: A Medieval Football Game, Still Going Strong
summary: In Ashbourne, England, thousands of residents join in an annual match that has defined the town for centuries.. At 2 p.m. last Tuesday, in a parking lot in the ancient English market town of Ashbourne in the Derbyshire Dales, an elderly man climbed onto a brick plinth in front of a crowd of some 3,000 people. As two Union Jacks flapped in a chill wind behind him, he held up a large, ornately painted leather ball. Those closest to him could see that it had the date and his name-Andrew "Cluck" Lemon-inscribed on it. Then he threw the ball where the crowd was packed the tightest, into a knot of muscular men dressed in sports jerseys and tracksuits.

title: London Stock Exchange's Future Depends on Brussels
summary: Investors may be too relaxed about two European Union decisions that are crucial to the company's growth plans. London Stock Exchange Group's future isn't quite the sure thing investors seem to think.

title: FDA Cites Shortage of One Drug, Exposing Supply-Line Worry
summary: China is key supplier of chemical and raw materials and other pharmaceutical ingredients for medicines. Factory shutdowns across China because of the new coronavirus have exposed an uncomfortable health-care reality: Many medicines rely on raw materials that are made in that country.

title: Chart How the Virus Upended Markets
summary: Markets have been shaken up by the spread of the virus-here's what's behind the moves. Several volatile trading sessions have wiped trillions of dollars of value from global stocks. Here's how markets are behaving and what they are signaling.

title: Canada Eked Out Growth in Fourth Quarter
summary: Weakest quarterly performance in over three years fueled by export, business investment declines; fear of repeat in first quarter of 2020. OTTAWA-The Canadian economy barely grew in the final three months of 2019, as declines in exports and business investment contributed to the weakest quarter of activity in over three years.

title: 'Socialism': A Disputed Name for a Cause, From Marx to Bernie Sanders
summary: Since the term first appeared in English in the 19th century, what it signifies has depended on who uses it and whether they are for it or against it. During the presidential primary season, Sen. Bernie Sanders has been assailed by Republicans and moderate Democrats alike over one contentious word: "socialism."

title: Three Questions With NYX Cosmetics Founder Toni Ko
summary: 'The chase is a lot more fun than the kill itself'. Toni Ko was in her mid-20s when she started her makeup company, NYX Cosmetics. With seed money from her mother, the Korean immigrant transformed the business from a solo operation into a company that was eventually acquired by L'Oreal SA for a reported $500 million.

title: Should Amazon Be Responsible When Its Vendors' Products Turn Out to Be Unsafe?
summary: Critics of Amazon say legal precedents justify holding the company liable for third-party sellers' products. Others say Amazon's scale makes it unfeasible to do so.. What exactly is Amazon.com ?

title: Five Men's Accessories Inspired by Nature
summary: There's a natural appeal to the best accessories of the season, which feature organic elements, from an Hermès commuter bag to studded Loewe slides. THE BAG A luxe leather tote for straphangers. Hermès bag, $6,000, Hermès stores nationwide

title: Make Your Trench an XL
summary: A mix of oversize tailoring and workwear makes for a new take on traditional utility garments. See inside the new menswear trend. GET SMART A streamlined trench pulls it all together. Jil Sander coat, $1,764, jilsander.com, Prada shirt, $780, select Prada boutiques, Risdon & Risdon apron, $165, risdonandrisdon.co.uk, Craig Green pants, price upon request, Dover Street Market, 160 Lexington Avenue, New York, Bottega Veneta shoes, $1,650, bottegaveneta.com

title: The College Basketball Season Without a Household Name
summary: Zion Williamson dominated the sport in 2019. This year, it's a season without One Great Team or One Transcendent Player.. Last winter, a certain 6-foot-7, 285-pound Duke freshman dominated the court and the airwaves: Zion Williamson was quite literally the biggest thing to hit college basketball in decades. Making it to March without knowing his name would have required hibernation.

title: Drought Fears Rise in California
summary: Lack of rain depletes snowpack on which state relies for water; scientists cite climate change as possible cause. California's mountain snowpack is about half its normal level, raising fears that the state could return to drought after a string of mostly abundant wet years.

title: Nike's Offer to U.S. Olympic Marathon Trials Runners: Free Shoes
summary: The offer of Air Zoom Alphafly NEXT%s from the brand that upended shoe design forces a quick decision. ATLANTA-More than 700 runners qualified for Saturday's U.S. Olympic marathon trials. That's the largest-ever group of men and women to try to finish among the top three men or women and make Team USA.

title: Hong Kong Says Pets of Coronavirus Patients Need to Be Quarantined
summary: Dog belonging to an infected person produced a 'weak positive' test result, authorities say. The Hong Kong government said pets of coronavirus patients must be quarantined, after a dog belonging to an infected person in the city tested mildly positive for the respiratory illness.

title: The Coronavirus Selloff Might Be Exaggerated
summary: Bets against market volatility and an excess of confidence among investors might be amplifying the rout beyond rational calculations of the outbreak's spread. Forget the 2007 collapse and the dot-com bubble bursting in 2000: The coronavirus has now officially engineered the fastest-ever correction in U.S. stocks from their peak. Investors may take solace in the fact that, if this seems a bit exaggerated, it is because it could be.

title: Joe Biden's South Carolina 'Firewall' Faces Test with Black Voters
summary: Resume Subscription. ALLENDALE, S.C.-If South Carolina is former Vice President Joe Biden's firewall against Sen. Bernie Sanders in the Democratic presidential primary race, interviews with black voters here indicate some cracks have formed.

title: The Secret History of Los Angeles, An Urban Explorer's Guide
summary: Most visitors might smirk at the idea of 'old' in a city obsessed with reinvention. But L.A.'s romanticized past is in vogue, with the newest hot spots housed in reborn relics. Here, the hotels, classic restaurants, rooftop bars and gilded theaters that are buzzing again. THE MOST ECCENTRIC historical trail in Los Angeles County starts on a quiet suburban road above Pasadena. A 3-mile steep climb, past chaparral and wildflowers, leads to the ruined foundations of Echo Mountain House, a 70-room resort opened in 1894, complete with a Swiss-style chalet and astronomical observatory. On a recent Sunday morning, I clambered over the site's cracked stone steps and found rusting train tracks and giant cogs in the underbrush, remains of a cable railway that once brought Gilded Age holidaymakers in top hats and bustle dresses to these heights.

title: South Korea Spends Billions to Blunt Coronavirus's Economic Impact
summary: In Japan, Hokkaido prefecture declares state of emergency, while China reports epidemic's growth is slowing. South Korea injected more than $13 billion in emergency funds to stoke economic activity sapped by the fast-spreading coronavirus, while a regional government in Japan declared a state of emergency in a bid to contain its own outbreak.

title: Bond Bulls Have Time in the Sun, While Fed Put Gets Roughed Up
summary: Central bank has less firepower now to combat a downturn than in the past. Any expectation that the coronavirus epidemic would bypass the U.S. stock market disappeared this week as stocks careened. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell more than 1,000 points on Monday, and then fell nearly 1,200 points on Thursday as all the major indexes tumbled into correction territory. The Dow's six-session losing streak is its worst since November 2008. Meanwhile, haven assets like bonds and gold continue to see money piling in, with the yield on the benchmark 10-year note setting a record low.

title: Stocks to Watch: Dell, Beyond Meat, Occidental Petroleum
summary: Here are some of the companies with stocks expected to trade actively in Friday's session. Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Friday's session. Stock movements noted by ticker reflect movements during regular trading hours.

title: Euro's Surge Shows Power of Carry Trades Unwinding
summary: Eurozone currency has rallied against the dollar even though the economy looks set for a shock. The euro has rallied against the dollar this week, contrary to what might be expected in a weak economy that has the biggest outbreak of coronavirus outside of Asia.

title: China's Advertising Vanguard Keeps Getting Disrupted
summary: The coronavirus is weighing on online advertising in the country, but that isn't the biggest problem for Baidu and Weibo. People are spending more time in the virtual world these days, but a real-world epidemic could still hurt online advertising platforms in China.

title: Research Ties Historic Black Names to Longer Life
summary: In late 1800s and early 1900s, African-American men with distinctively black names lived longer than their peers, new study finds. Distinctively black names are often tied to naming conventions that emerged during the Civil Rights era.

title: Southern Democrats Say Sanders Nomination Would Hurt Down-Ballot Candidates
summary: Party leaders in Carolinas, Florida worry about a democratic socialist as the Democratic nominee. MYRTLE BEACH, S.C.-Some Democrats in Southern states from North Carolina to Florida are anxious about Bernie Sanders winning the Democratic presidential nomination, saying it could jeopardize a closely-won governor's seat, reverse recent gains in state legislatures and turn what might be competitive congressional races into GOP landslides.

title: Democrats Give Cold Shoulder to Big Wall Street Donor
summary: M&A lawyer H. Rodgin Cohen is shunned over financial-crisis and Weinstein roles; public health experts express alarm at Trump officials' rhetoric on virus. DEMOCRATS' WARINESS OF WALL STREET MONEY has complicated the political giving of one of the Street's most prominent M&A lawyers.

title: Coronavirus Outbreak Gives Rise to More Complex Forms of Remote Work
summary: Workers in China are using remote platforms to hold meetings, follow health status of colleagues. The coronavirus outbreak has spurred a rise in the use of virtual-meeting and work platforms that go beyond simple videoconferences, companies in China say.

title: Swarms of Locusts Destroy Huge Swaths of Farmland in East Africa
summary: Resume Subscription. KAMPALA, Uganda-Across Somalia, desert locusts in a swarm the size of Manhattan have destroyed a swath of farmland as big as Oklahoma. In Kenya, billions-strong clouds of the insects have eaten through 800 square miles of crops and survived a weekslong spraying campaign. In parts of Pakistan, the pests have eaten 40% of the harvest, forcing the government to declare a national emergency.

title: Benny Gantz Puts His Anti-Netanyahu Coalition Up to a Vote for Third Time
summary: Former army chief of staff seeks to draw voters disenchanted with long-serving incumbent. TEL AVIV-Days ahead of Israel's third election in less than a year, prime minister hopeful Benny Gantz has cobbled together a disparate coalition of politicians who are united largely in their antipathy for Benjamin Netanyahu, the current holder of that office.

title: Turkish Troop Losses Mount in Battle for Syria's Last Rebel Stronghold
summary: Despite reinforcements from Ankara, rebels fighting Russian-backed Assad regime are losing ground. REYHANLI, Turkey-At least 33 Turkish soldiers were killed in northwestern Syria on Thursday, Turkish officials said, plunging Turkey deeper into the war there, as a Russian-backed Syrian military offensive sought to reclaim the last rebel stronghold.

title: Baidu Warns of Revenue Drop, Signaling Trouble for China's Private Sector
summary: Chinese search provider is among the latest Chinese companies to be hit by the coronavirus epidemic that has affected swaths of the country's economy. BEIJING-Chinese search-engine giant Baidu Inc. warned its first-quarter revenue could drop 5% to 13% as the coronavirus epidemic wallops many of the sectors that fuel its bread-and-butter advertising business.

title: Activist Investor Robbins Closing His Firm
summary: The $2 billion fund is latest hedge fund to call it quits as market dynamics shift toward lower fees and more 'passive' investing processes. Activist investor Clifton S. Robbins is closing his firm, the latest high-profile veteran to exit the hedge-fund business. His motivation appears to be different from his rivals, however.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Senate OKs $1 Billion for Rural Telecom Carriers to Replace Huawei Gear
summary: If signed by president, the bill will provide funds for about 40 rural carriers that use the Chinese company's equipment. WASHINGTON-The U.S. Senate approved legislation that would provide $1 billion for rural telecom carriers to replace equipment made by China's Huawei Technologies Co. in their networks.

title: India Begins Probe of Clashes That Left 38 Dead
summary: Authorities try to calm tensions in capital area after violence that coincided with Trump visit. NEW DELHI-Indian authorities tried to calm tensions in the nation's capital and began investigating four days of rioting and clashes between Hindus and Muslims that left at least 38 dead and more than 300 injured in the worst violence the capital has seen in decades.

title: First Sanctioned Supervised Drug Site in U.S. Hits Another Snag
summary: Despite court's green light, opposition from neighbors has halted plan for safe-injection location in South Philadelphia. Plans to open the nation's first sanctioned supervised drug-use site in Philadelphia next week have quickly unraveled due to blowback from potential neighbors.

title: Coronavirus Cases Hit Professional Cycling as Elite Race Is Canceled
summary: The UAE Tour came to an abrupt halt after a team confirmed two cases on its staff. An elite bicycle race in the Persian Gulf might have seemed an unlikely candidate to be disrupted by the global coronavirus outbreak. But on Thursday evening, the globe-trotting sport of professional cycling joined the list when a weeklong event in the United Arab Emirates was canceled midway through due to two confirmed cases of the illness.

title: Trump Backs Limits on Secret Surveillance Court
summary: Sen. Rand Paul says the president approved of his amendment to overhaul FISA. WASHINGTON-President Trump has signaled his support for a measure that would prohibit the U.S. government from turning to a secretive surveillance court to get wiretaps on Americans, according to a White House official, setting up a potential clash between the president and the intelligence community.

title: Cisco Plans New Round of Layoffs
summary: Networking-equipment company faces prospect of slowing sales growth. Cisco Systems Inc. has started a new round of job cuts as the networking-equipment maker faces the prospect of slowing sales growth because of global economic uncertainty.

title: Staying In Worked During the Stock-Market Rout. Dining Out Didn't.
summary: Why Domino's Pizza, Clorox rallied during the market's selloff-and Shake Shack, Madison Square Garden trailed behind. Global markets have been on a roller-coaster ride the past week. The coronavirus epidemic is spreading rapidly, and analysts say there is no telling how big of a hit the economy will take as a result.

title: DoorDash Files Confidentially for IPO
summary: Move sets up the food-delivery provider to go public as soon as this spring. Food-delivery provider DoorDash Inc. has filed for an initial public offering, firing the starting gun on what could be one of the year's marquee listings.

title: U.S. Stocks Slide Into a Correction as Virus Fears Show No Sign of Easing
summary: Dow, S&P, Nasdaq all drop more than 4% in largest one-day point declines on record. The February market rout deepened Thursday, as major stock indexes around the globe posted another round of significant declines and uncertainty over the impact of the coronavirus began shading into fear.

title: The Coronavirus Isn't Partisan
summary: Maybe we should quarantine Capitol Hill until the crisis passes.. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer opened a joint statement Thursday on federal coronavirus policy with this line: "Lives are at stake-this is not the time for name-calling or playing politics." As the saying goes, interesting if true. The evidence so far of bipartisan cooperation in response to the virus isn't promising. Actually, it's depressing.

title: Bernie Sanders's Ejection Fraction
summary: He says he released a 'full report' of his heart attack. Not quite.. Despite his heart attack last fall, Bernie Sanders has not released detailed medical records, the way John McCain did in 2008. Rather, Mr. Sanders has posted doctor's notes attesting to his vitality. One example of what's missing, an NBC report noted this week, is a metric of heart health called "left ventricular ejection fraction."

title: The BlackRock Backlash
summary: Larry Fink's political machinations invite regulatory scrutiny.. BlackRock manages some $7.4 trillion in financial assets, and CEO Larry Fink has been flexing his influence by ordering companies to follow his political dictates on social justice and climate issues. In the process he may be putting BlackRock and other asset managers in the political dock.

title: Psst . . . I Want You to Illegally Immigrate
summary: Solicitation or free speech? The Supreme Court takes up the case.. Acting to "encourage" illegal immigration is itself against the law. Is this a sensible ban on solicitation? Or a First Amendment violation that could make a criminal of "a loving grandmother who urges her grandson to overstay his visa"? That theoretical was cited in 2018 when the law was struck down by the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.

title: FCC Probe Finds Mobile Carriers Didn't Safeguard Location Data
summary: AT&T, T-Mobile among companies facing hundreds of millions of dollars in fines, though they will likely fight decision. The Federal Communications Commission is seeking hundreds of millions of dollars in fines from the country's top cellphone carriers after officials found the companies failed to safeguard information about customers' real-time locations, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: VA Secretary Under Investigation for Handling of Sexual-Assault Case
summary: Department's inspector general launches probe into allegations that Robert Wilkie sought to discredit Andrea Goldstein, who claimed she was assaulted at VA hospital. The Department of Veterans Affairs' internal watchdog has launched an investigation into allegations that Secretary Robert Wilkie attempted to discredit a woman who alleged she was sexually assaulted at a department medical center, the department's inspector general said Thursday.

title: Grand Central Terminal Restaurateur Won't Pay Rent Over Homeless Issue
summary: MTA has said that it planned to renovate the dining concourse, and officials have said they would increase efforts to fight homelessness. A Grand Central Terminal restaurateur is refusing to pay $260,000 in rent and fees to New York's Metropolitan Transportation Authority because he says a growing homeless population in the landmark station is hurting business.

title: Amtrak to Begin Repairs to Tunnels Beneath Hudson River
summary: Transportation Secretary Elaine Chao says work on aging tunnels can't wait for prospect of new ones. WASHINGTON-Amtrak is planning to begin major repairs on the aging railroad tunnels beneath the Hudson River that link New Jersey and New York, with officials saying they can no longer wait for new tunnels to be built.
